page.title: 20SCHOOL CHRISTINGLE SERVICE
page.content: Each year in the last week of the Christmas Term, the children of the school attend St. Michael's Church for a Christingle Service. A Christingle is an orange which is decorated in a symbolic way to remind us of Jesus. The orange represents the world. Around the orange is a red band which symbolises Christ's blood. Four cocktail sticks piercing currants and nuts are stuck into the orange and these represent the four seasons and the fruits of the world. The top of the orange is cored and a candle is pushed into the hole. This represents the 'light' of the world. These Christingles are made in school by eager children. About a week before the service each child is given an envelope in which he is expected to collect money.This is exchanged for a lit Christingle during the service.
